IRenderer

Defines our basic renderer. IRenderer handles all rendering commands.  It is generally expected that this object is running on its own thread.

Module

import Rendering.Caustic.IRenderer;

Functions

) = 0

DrawScreenQuadWithCustomShader
virtual void DrawScreenQuadWithCustomShader(
IShader* pShader,
float minU,
float minV,
float maxU,
float maxV,
ITexture* pTexture,
ISampler* pSampler,
bool disableDepth = false
) = 0

Renders a quad on the display at the specified uv coordinates.  A full screen quad runs from 0.0,0.0 => 1.0,1.0

Parameters
pShader
IShader*

shader to use. The method expects the shader to contain the following variables:

tex

texture to use

s

sampler

minu
float

min UV coordinate where quad is to be drawn

minv
float

min UV coordinate where quad is to be drawn

maxu
float

max UV coordinate where quad is to be drawn

maxv
float

max UV coordinate where quad is to be drawn

minU
float

minimum U

minV
float

minimum V

maxU
float

maximum U

maxV
float

maximum V

pTexture
ITexture*

Texture to render on quad

pSampler
ISampler*

Sampler to use. Maybe nullptr

disableDepth
bool

disable depth mapping?

Setup
virtual void Setup(
HWND hwnd,
std::wstring &shaderFolder,
bool createDebugDevice,
bool startFrozen = false,
int desktopIndex = 0
) = 0

Initializes the renderer. Applications need to call this method at startup.

Parameters
hwnd
HWND

window to bind renderer to

shaderFolder
std::wstring&

path to shader folder

createDebugDevice
bool

True if application wants the debug D3D device. False otherwise.

startFrozen
bool

start renderer in a frozen state.

desktopIndex
int

index indicating which desktop duplication service will use

DrawMesh
virtual void DrawMesh(
IRenderSubMesh *pMesh,
IMaterialAttrib *pMaterial,
ITexture *pTexture,
IShader *pShader,
DirectX::XMMATRIX &mat
) = 0

Renders a mesh by adding it to the Renderable list that is drawn each time a frame is rendered

TODO: This method needs to be refactored. There is no point in sending in both a pMaterial and a pTexture (the material already should define the diffuse texture). Also, we should pass in both a front and back face material

Parameters
pMesh
IRenderSubMesh*

mesh to render

pMaterial
IMaterialAttrib*

material for front faces

pTexture
ITexture*

texture for diffuse component

pShader
IShader*

shader to use to draw mesh

mat
DirectX::XMMATRIX&

matrix to transform mesh by

SetFinalRenderTarget
virtual void SetFinalRenderTarget(
ID3D11Texture2D* pTexture
) = 0

Sets the final render target. This allows for the final output to be something other than the default window.

Parameters
pTexture
ID3D11Texture2D*

Texture to use as final render target

SetFinalRenderTargetUsingSharedTexture
virtual void SetFinalRenderTargetUsingSharedTexture(
IUnknown* pTexture
) = 0

Sets the final render target. This method is only intended to be used by the WPF interop layer. It will assign the final render target using the shared textured that D3D11Image returns.

Parameters
pTexture
IUnknown*

Shared texture from D3D11Image (WPF Interop layer) to use as final render target

HWND hwnd,

int desktopIndex = 0
)

Creates a renderer

Parameters

std::wstring&

startFrozen
bool

should renderer be started in a frozen state?

desktopIndex
int

import Rendering.Caustic.IRenderer;
